dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains the concept of swapping two variables in Python, including the underlying mechanics and alternatives.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Provides a clear definition of swapping, explains why a temporary variable works, and demonstrates tuple unpacking with simple code snippets.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Uses vague terms, skips the reason behind each step, or mixes up assignment semantics.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, and engagement when walking through the swap code examples.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Speaks at a steady pace, emphasizes key syntax (e.g., '=', ',', '()'), and pauses before showing the result.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone, rushes through code, or uses filler words that obscure the logic.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of the lesson: introduction of the problem, explanation of the classic method, presentation of Pythonic tuple unpacking, and summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with a real‑world scenario, shows the three‑line temporary‑variable solution, then transitions to the one‑line tuple swap, ending with a recap of trade‑offs.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Jumping between code snippets without clear transitions, or omitting the summary.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interactive elements such as asking learners to predict output, encouraging them to try variations, and checking understanding.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Poses questions like 'What will be printed after this swap?' and invites students to modify the code for different data types.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Delivers a lecture‑only monologue with no prompts or checks for comprehension.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of the Python syntax and the explanation of how swapping works.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: All code runs without errors, correctly demonstrates both temporary variable and tuple unpacking methods.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Shows syntax errors, misstates that Python evaluates right‑to‑left, or claims the tuple method creates a temporary variable.
